div.p: 3.-5.9.2025: The WIBARAB project hosts the Arabic Linguistics Forum conference at the University of Vienna.
Spring 2025: The new TUNOCENT Website gets launched.

3.-4.10.2024: The WIBARAB project hosts its second Symposium titled Interdisciplinary Perspectives on the 'Tribe' in the WANA Region. Here, scholars from different disciplines such as history, (socio-)linguistics and social anthropology come together to discuss different aspects of the concept of 'tribe' and its many interpretations in different academic fields and thus contributing to the project's theoretical framework.

30.9.2024: The TUNOCENT project ends. After more than five years of intensive work, the results of the project are considerable: The TUNOCENt dataset now contains 71 profiles, 195 feature lists, 185 sample texts and 24 corpus texts. In addition, the metadata of all 2683 recordings can be browsed through.

23.7.2024:The ACDH hosts a meeting dedicated to digital lexicography: Members of the DARIAH Working Group on Lexical Resources and ACDH team members disuss various topics concerning TEI Lex-0. This is highly relevant for the VICAV dictionaries: the SHAWI dictionary is being encoded according to the Lex-0 specifications and it is planned to convert the other VIVACV dictionaries into Lex-0 in the future. Another topic that was discussed in this meeting are the finer points of the encoding of language varieties. Given that the language profiles are a vital part of the platform, this topic is of particular importance for VICAV, and the results of this discusseion might shape the VICAV profiles in the future.

1.12.2023: Laurent Romary, Director of Scientific Culture and Information at INRIA, visits Vienna again to join the WIBARAB team in discussions about the progress of the WIBARAB database and the setting-up of the project's digital text corpus.

7.-9.6.2023: The WIBARAB project hosts its first Symposium titled New Data and Fresh Perspectives. In three days, the team members present and discuss with the guests the project's ongoing work,preliminary results, and methodological and theoretical considerations.
February-March 2023: Two more fieldwork campaigns are conducted by members of the WIBARAB project take place. team. This time, the destinations are Jordan and Sudan.

20.5.2022: The Director of Scientific Culture and Information at INRIA, Laurent Romary, comes to Vienna to intensively discuss WIBARAB's TEI based linguistic database with the project team. Consequently, the database's data model is based on the results of this meeting.

January-May 2022: The first fieldwork campaigns of the WIBARAB project take place. Members of the team go to Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Morocco, and Lebanon to collect data which will ultimately feed the WIBARAB database and form a text corpus.

1.10.2021: The WIBARAB project starts. WIBARAB (What is Bedouin-Type Arabic?) is funded by an ERC Advanced Grant (101020127-WIRARAB) and investigates the linguistic and socio-historical realities behind the millennia-old dichotomous concept of nomadic and sedentary people in the Middle East and North Africa. It will run for five years and will expand the VICAV infrastructure. A vital part of the WIBARAB project will be its linguistic database that will incorporate both previously published and newly gathered data on more than 300 Arabic varieties.
2.6.2021: With 20 new profiles there are now 106 profiles.

1.2.2021: The SHAWI project starts The project is funded by the Austrian Science fund (FWF, P-33574), and investigates the Arabic dialects of the so-called Shawi-type, wihich are spoken by small cattle breeding Bedouin tribes in regions of Turkey, Syria and Iraq. The SHAWI project builds on the VICAV infrastructure and will add to VICAV a sixth dictionary as well as a comparatively large corpus.
27.1.2021: Entirely revamped VICAV 3.0 goes public. The bibliography has now 4722 entries!
19.12.2020: The Baghdad dictionary has now over 1100 entries.
5.4.2019: Bettina Leitner has contributed a new feature list for Ahwaz (Iran).

1.4.2019: The TUNOCENT project starts. TUNOCENT (=Tunisiaâ€™s Linguistic terra incognita) investigates the Arabic varieties of northwestern and central Tunisia. It will run for four years and builds on the VICAV infrastructure.
18.3.2019: Our bibliography has just gone beyond the 4000 entries mark. The 4028 bibliographic items contain 6304 geo-tags and 13.045 taxonomy labels.
15.3.2019: New function to compare features.
1.3.2019: The Baghdad dictionary goes online.
28.2.2019: VICAV has 41 new profiles, all in all 58 profiles now!
2.2.2019: The VICAV Bibliography has undergone a substantial rebuild. All the bibliographical data is now also encoded in TEI (P5), all the VICAV data now being available in TEI.
3.12.2018: The cross dictionary search is finished. It is now possible to query all dictionaries simultaneously.
31.12.2016: The TUNICO project ends.
1.8.2013: The TUNICO project starts.
